data.title: Interesting Facts About The first Nobel Prize Winner of India: Sri Rabindranath Tagore
data.meta_description: Rabindranath Tagore, also called as Rabindranath Thakur by the Bengalis, was the first India to receive Nobel Prize for Literature in 1913. With this, he also became the first non-European to win the Nobel Prize.
data.text:
Gitanjali Awards

Gitanjali Awards

Director

Published May 30, 2017

Rabindranath Tagore, also called as Rabindranath Thakur by the Bengalis, was the first India to receive Nobel Prize for Literature in 1913. With this, he also became the first non-European to win the Nobel Prize. He received the accolade after publishing a collection of poems called as Gitanjali.

In the words of the authorities he won Nobel Prize because: "because of his profoundly sensitive, fresh and beautiful verse, by which, with consummate skill, he has made his poetic thought, expressed in his own English words, a part of the literature of the West"

Here are some interesting facts about Rabindranath Tagore.

Tagore was a great painter too and played an important role in modernising Bengali art.

He gave up his knighthood after the Jallianwala Bagh massacre to protest against British policies.

25th Baisakhi is a date of cultural importance in West Bengal. It is the birth anniversary of Rabindranath Tagore as per the Bengali calendar.

He was the first non-European to win the Nobel Prize.

He established his own university where humanity was studied which was beyond the conventional methods and topics of other universities.

His Visva-Bharati University was named Shantiniketan in 1921 and was declared central university in May 1951.

He is the only one to compose national anthems for three countries: India, Bangladesh, Sri Lanka.

Sri Lanka’s national anthem is based on a Bengali song originally written by Tagore in 1938. It was later translated into Sinhalese and became the national anthem in 1951.

He granted the title of 'Mahatma' on Mohandas Karamchand Gandhi in 1915.

He was the second after swami Vivekananda who addressed the World-Parliament of Religions.

His contribution in literature include nearly 50 dramas, 100 books, 40 novels and short fiction stories.

Rabindranath tagore was one of the few jewels of India who showed what greatness means with his literary works. He has imprinted on us as one of the greatest personalities to walk the Earth, and to many, as the revered Gurudev.
